accused.name: la Grande Marye
accused.spouse_name: Didier Sotterel (also called Didier de Faulceray, marechal)

confession.seduction_context: After a quarrel with her husband

testimony.quarrel_subject: When he was a child, his father quarreled with her husband and they fought; she interposed herself and his father called her witch
testimony.threat_quote: She threatened to take him to law; he responded with threats that he would have her burned and her goods confiscated

harms_alleged.harm_description: painfully swollen thigh, 9 weeks in bed
devastating hailstorm towards end of harvest
harms_alleged.method_alleged: Saw accused and 2 of her children acting strangely in fields; each child held a 'vergatte' a yard long

testimony.quarrel_subject: One of Marye's daughters was refused flour and butter because they were poor and lived by husband's work
testimony.threat_quote: The girl said they would repent

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: 2 days later child sickened, dying 2 weeks later (6 years before testimony)

harms_alleged.harm_description: great pains in eyes and seemed likely to lose her sight
harms_alleged.method_alleged: Recovered after Marye visited house uninvited, looked at eyes, and advised pilgrimage to Beau Bernard at Vic; sickness returned after Marye refused bread given in thanks; cured after 2 further pilgrimages

testimony.quarrel_subject: Son insulted Marye saying 'En a tu assez, grande genoxe' when she asked where he was going

harms_alleged.harm_description: fell ill next day, died a month later
harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: 7 years before testimony; next day after insult
harms_alleged.method_alleged: chased him into house and beat him

testimony.quarrel_subject: Marye wrongly accused son of witness of theft from a third party

witnesses.name: Jehenne Vannier, femme Henry de Frumesnil

testimony.threat_quote: qu'en mal griefve santé y puise elle entrer et en mal griefve santé retourner

harms_alleged.harm_description: fell ill and had to return home out of her right mind
harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: 10 or 11 years earlier; 2 days after passing Marye's house on way to wedding feast
harms_alleged.method_alleged: Marye cursed her when she passed dressed well for wedding where Marye was not invited (though she was aunt to one getting married)

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: 16 years earlier, after quarrel with wife

harms_alleged.harm_description: painful hole in her foot which tormented her until death 10 years later

testimony.threat_quote: souhaiter que malencontre et malle fortune luy puisse advenir

testimony.quarrel_subject: Witness opposed Marie being taken in by her husband because of her reputation; Marie was angry and made a scene when witness took other neighbor some food

harms_alleged.harm_description: serious back pains, periodically afflicted 3 years later
became ill, troubled in her wits and behaving as if frenetic; now less troublesome since age and illness left her 'fort debille'
harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: 16 years earlier, after quarrel and fight

testimony.threat_quote: putain ribaulde de prebtre que tu es, tu as la pance pleine Mais je te promet que quand elle sera vide je te feray mener la plus beau train qu'oncques femme mena

harms_alleged.harm_description: became totally frantic and out of her mind for at least half a year after giving birth
harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: 27 years earlier; immediately after birth following Marye's threat to pregnant woman

harms_alleged.attributed_to: la Grande Marye (attributed to her brother's household)
harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: within 2 weeks of quarrels with household of accused's brother

harms_alleged.harm_description: horse sickened and had fallen down; recovered after Marye touched it

testimony.quarrel_subject: Disputes while working together; Marie was 'fiere et haultaine'
testimony.threat_quote: de luy faire garder son feu plus de sept ans

harms_alleged.harm_description: accident when loading cart at hay harvest - crippled and had to walk with a stick
harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: 15 years earlier; at next hay harvest after threat

timeline.subject: la Grande Marye
timeline.details: Confronted with witnesses; attacked their credibility, accused several of theft

timeline.subject: la Grande Marye
timeline.details: Change de Nancy agrees 'avec discretion et mediocrité requise'

timeline.subject: la Grande Marye
timeline.details: Racked and given thumbscrews for half hour, then after dinner placed on rack for further half-hour with addition of tortillons; denied all charges despite torture

timeline.subject: la Grande Marye
timeline.details: Called judges and offered to make full confession

timeline.subject: la Grande Marye
timeline.details: Change de Nancy approves, subject to final confirmation of confessions

notable_quotes.speaker: la Grande Marye (to pregnant la petite Didier)
notable_quotes.french: putain ribaulde de prebtre que tu es, tu as la pance pleine Mais je te promet que quand elle sera vide je te feray mener la plus beau train qu'oncques femme mena
notable_quotes.english: you priest's whore slut, you have a full belly but I promise you that when it is empty I will make you dance the finest dance any woman ever danced
notable_quotes.context: Quarrel with pregnant neighbor; witness intervened with hatchet to prevent violence

notable_quotes.speaker: la Grande Marye (to Jehenne Vannier)
notable_quotes.french: qu'en mal griefve santé y puise elle entrer et en mal griefve santé retourner
notable_quotes.english: may she enter in bad grievous health and return in bad grievous health
notable_quotes.context: Curse directed at Jehenne on her way to wedding feast where Marye was not invited

notable_quotes.speaker: la Grande Marye (to Meline femme Anthoine Grand Anthoine)
notable_quotes.french: souhaiter que malencontre et malle fortune luy puisse advenir
notable_quotes.english: wishing that misfortune and bad fortune may happen to her

notable_quotes.speaker: la Grande Marye (to Mengeotte)
notable_quotes.french: de luy faire garder son feu plus de sept ans
notable_quotes.english: to make her keep her fire for more than seven years

notable_quotes.speaker: Poirson Halbry's son (to la Grande Marye)
notable_quotes.french: En a tu assez, grande genoxe
notable_quotes.context: Boy's insult to Marye when she asked where he was going; she then chased and beat him, he fell ill and died

notable_quotes.speaker: la Grande Marye (about Didier, first wife of Gros Henry Margeron)
notable_quotes.french: qu'elle est morte bien pauvrement et couroit apres les prestres et les gens de guerre
notable_quotes.english: that she died very poorly and ran after the priests and the men of war
notable_quotes.context: During interrogation, dismissive comment about deceased

notable_quotes.speaker: Judges (about la Grande Marye under torture)
notable_quotes.french: que l'avons trouvé fort oppiniastre et disposé a endurer tous tourmentz avec resolution de plustost mourir que rien confesser
notable_quotes.english: that we found her very obstinate and disposed to endure all torments with resolution to rather die than confess anything
notable_quotes.context: Judges' observation after first torture session

relationships.evidence_text: veuve Didier Sotterel; Had been married for 20 years to Didier de Faulceray, marechal, who had died about 12 years earlier
daughter of Ferry Jean Vannier and his wife Barbeline
accused's brother, the late Jean Bon Claude

relationships.person2: one getting married at wedding feast
relationships.evidence_text: la grande Marye, who was aunt to one of those getting married
husband and wife; witness #6 and witness #9
husband and wife; witness #11 and witness #13
Jehenne Vannier, femme Henry de Frumesnil
Had been her neighbour for a year
She had been invited as relative

relationships.person2: son of Didier Colin at Embermesnil
relationships.evidence_text: was in service with son of Didier Colin at Embermesnil

economic_context.details: Accused was poor and lived by her husband's work (as marechal); after his death appeared to live in poverty. Multiple references to her poverty: daughters refused flour and butter 'because they were poor', confession mentioned 'since she was poor she wanted to preserve the crops'. Dispute over plum tarts also suggests poverty/food scarcity.

Marye carried child in cradle on her head
Marye refused bread offered in sign of thanks by Nicolas Mongenan's wife
One of Marye's daughters was refused flour
One of Marye's daughters was refused butter
Odille did not give Marye plum tarts, leading to revenge
Marye accused Jehenne Vannier of stealing a shirt
Marye accused Mengeatte of stealing and cooking geese
Nicolas Marchal's wife accused Marye of stealing an écu
Michel Hellenix intervened with hatchet to protect pregnant woman from Marye
Nicolas Mongenan took his wife on cart to pilgrimage; Mengeotte had accident loading cart
Mengeotte had to walk with stick after being crippled
Michel Hellenix's mother trying to make sick horse eat grass
Rushing to recover grain from hailstorm; accusations of stealing corn/tithes

spatial_references.context: Primary location of trial; residence of accused and most witnesses
Pilgrimage site for healing; Nicolas Mongenan's wife and Jehenne Vannier went there to recover from illnesses
Jehenne Vannier was in service with son of Didier Colin at Embermesnil
Where hailstorm occurred; where Marye and children were seen with wands
Witness saw mysterious hare in cemetery during illness of Poirson Hanry's son
Poirson Hanry's son was going to church to see if curé was available for confession
Jehenne Vannier passed Marye's house on way to wedding; various neighbors lived near

historical_context.military_details: Reference to 'gens de guerre' (men of war) - Marye said of Didier 'qu'elle est morte bien pauvrement et couroit apres les prestres et les gens de guerre'
weather_events: devastating hailstorm towards end of harvest (21 years before, approximately 1581)
economic_hardship_indicators: accused was poor and lived by husband's work
daughters refused flour and butter because they were poor
Mengeotte depended on day labour for livelihood
disputes over food (plum tarts, flour, butter)
religious_calendar_references: pardon (religious pardon that witness wanted to take advantage of)
pilgrimage to Beau Bernard at Vic

prior_legal_disputes.description: When Nicolas le Clerc's father called Marye witch, she threatened to take him to law
prior_legal_disputes.outcome: He responded with threats to have her burned

prior_legal_disputes.description: Multiple accusations of theft during confrontations - Marye accused witnesses of stealing corn, shirts, geese; was herself accused of stealing écu

legal_context.redress_outcome: Threatened to take Nicolas le Clerc's father to law for calling her witch, but he counter-threatened to have her burned

emotional_state_notes: disposé a endurer tous tourmentz avec resolution de plustost mourir que rien confesser (disposed to endure all torments with resolution to rather die than confess anything)
fiere et de haulte courage (proud and of high courage)

reproaches_to_witnesses.objection: Attacked Michiel Hellenix on grounds he had stolen corn belonging to local church
Said of Hellenix femme Demenge Conna that her husband and she had formed granaries to take and steal wheat, and that she held the sack while her husband stuffed and diverted from the granary
Said his mother had suffered from 'mal St Anthoine' - her son had it too in his leg, and they had made pilgrimages together
Accused Jehenne Vannier of having stolen a shirt, so that she was known as a thief
Accused Mengeatte of stealing and cooking some geese
Said that Claudon Thomas was damned for deposing as he had, since it was untrue
Accused Jean Gadot of stealing tithes

third_parties.name: Demenge Didier Renard (Nicolas le Clerc's father)
third_parties.context: Called Marye witch; threatened to have her burned; lost cows

third_parties.name: Didier, first wife of Gros Henry Margeron
third_parties.context: Marye said dismissively of her 'qu'elle est morte bien pauvrement et couroit apres les prestres et les gens de guerre'

third_parties.name: la petite Didier
third_parties.context: Pregnant neighbor who Marye quarreled with violently; became frantic after giving birth

third_parties.name: Demenge Colbay
third_parties.context: Marye denied causing death of his daughter in confession

third_parties.name: Nicolas Marchal
third_parties.context: His wife accused Marye of stealing an écu; Marye caused her eye trouble in revenge

third_parties.name: Poirson Halbix (Poirson Halbry)

third_parties.name: curé
third_parties.context: Poirson Halbry's son was going to church to see if curé was available to hear his mother's confession

third_parties.name: son of Didier Colin
third_parties.context: Jehenne was in service with him at Embermesnil

third_parties.name: Jean Bon Claude
third_parties.context: His daughter married late Nicolas Pierson; wedding feast Jehenne attended

third_parties.context: Married daughter of Jean Bon Claude

third_parties.name: Demenge Grand Colas
third_parties.context: His father employed Mengeotte and Marye for day labour

extraction_metadata.notes: Extremely detailed trial record with 17 witnesses, extensive testimony about quarrels and alleged harms, torture session, confession, and execution. Trial demonstrates classic patterns: long-standing reputation (up to 40 years), multiple quarrels over food/resources, threats followed by harms, ambiguous healing/harming powers, and eventual confession after torture. Marye was characterized as proud and fierce, defended herself vigorously by attacking witnesses' credibility, but ultimately confessed after showing remarkable resistance to torture.
